text.text:
Crossmodal Research Laboratory, Department of Experimental Psychology, Tinbergen Building, 9 South Parks Road, Oxford, OX1 3UD, England. Researcher Contact Details: Carlos Velasco (Email: carlos.velasco@psy.ox.ac.uk)
Dear participant, Welcome to our study! We are the Crossmodal Research Laboratory, Department of Experimental Psychology, Oxford University. We are interested in understanding how people evaluate different objects. If you decide to take part in this experiment, you will be asked to rate different objects with specific word descriptors. There are no right or wrong responses, so please respond according to what feels right to you. We hope you enjoy it. Your participation is very important to us. You are being invited to participate because you are a member of the Prolific Academic online participant panel. The questionnaire will take around 10 minutes to complete. You would still be free to withdraw from the study at any time during the questionnaire, without needing to give a reason, and without penalty. The data will be fully anonymized, and stored on a secure computer at the Crossmodal Research Laboratory, University of Oxford. The data will only be accessible by members of the Crossmodal Research Laboratory. Prolific Academic staff will not be able to access your responses. This research has been reviewed by and received favourable opinion through the University of Oxford Central University Research Ethics Committee.

TRIAL.text: <.text>Before we begin, please read below. By clicking I CONSENT you indicate you have consented to take part. If you decide to take part in this experiment, you will be asked to look at some different objects and will be asked to rate them with specific word descriptors. At the end of the study we will tell you more about the purpose of the study and why we are doing this research. You can also contact Carlos Velasco (Email: carlos.velasco@psy.ox.ac.uk) for further information at a later date if you wish. If you have a concern about any aspect of this project, please contact the chair of the Medical Sciences Inter-divisional Research Ethics Committee at the University of Oxford (Chair, MS IDREC; Email: ethics@medsci.ox.ac.uk; Address: Research Services, University of Oxford, Wellington Square, Oxford OX1 2JD). The chair will seek to resolve the matter in a reasonably expeditious manner. Please read the below consent statement and indicate whether you consent. Statement of informed consent 1. I have read and understand the information above and understand the general purpose of this experiment. 2. I understand that I can withdraw from the questionnaire at any time, for any reason, and without penalty, and that doing so will destroy my data. (NB – Please be aware that data collected is anonymous – if you change your mind after completing the experiment, we will be unable to trace your specific data to remove it). 3. I understand how to raise a concern or make a complaint (detailed above). 4. I understand that my responses are anonymous. 5. I agree to take part in this online experiment. </.text>

text.text: What is your Prolific Academic ID?
What country do you come from?

On each trial you will see a picture. Below each picture you will see a 5-point scale anchored with two words, one on the right and one on the left.
Please rate the picture on the scale, by pressing a number from 1 (more associated to the word on the left) to 5 (more associated to the word on the right) on the computer keyboard.
Please respond as fast but as accurately as possible.
You are half way. Have a break if you want, then press SPACE to continue.
Please rate the item on the below scale by pressing the appropriate button.

TRIAL.text: <.text>“Approach and avoidance to shape features Thank-you for completing our study! The aim of this research was to investigate whether object valence (positive or negative) and contour (angular vs. round) and/or symmetry (symmetrical vs. asymmetrical) influence peoples associations of the objects with approach and avoidance words. Previous research seems to suggest that round and symmetrical objects ten to be associated with approach words whereas angular and assymetrical objects tend to be associated with avoidance words instead. Here, we also manipulated the valence of the object, that is, whether the object is associated with positive (a cake) or negative emotions (a knife). The results of this study will not include your name or any other information that could be used to identify you. This research did not use deception. If you have any further questions, please contact Carlos Velasco (Email: carlos.velasco@psy.ox.ac.uk). If you have a concern about any aspect of this project, please contact the chair of the Medical Sciences Inter-divisional Research Ethics Committee at the University of Oxford (Chair, MS IDREC; Email: ethics@medsci.ox.ac.uk; Address: Research Services, University of Oxford, Wellington Square, Oxford OX1 2JD). The chair will seek to resolve the matter in a reasonably expeditious manner. PLEASE REMEMBER TO VISIT THE BELOW LINK SO PROLFIC ACADEMIC KNOWS YOU HAVE COMPLETED THE STUDY. THANKS. </.text>
